sourceDesc.bibl: Planned Parenthood Group Defended by Mrs. Sanger. Tucson Daily Citizen, Sept. 10, 1959

docBody.head: Planned Parenthood Group Defended by Mrs. Sanger

p.q: A new round in the battle over birth control was shaping up today with Margaret Sanger of Tucson rushing to the defense of Planned Parenthood of Phoenix, Inc.
That organization was warned yesterday it apparently is violating a little-known. 20-year old law by distributing birth control literature.

docBody.p: "The Phoenix clinic has to get a good lawyer and show it is doing nothing illegal," Mrs. Sanger said here today.

p.q: Planned Parenthood Clinic of Tucson, 55 E. Jackson St., also distributed literature through individuals and by the mail.
Officials of the Phoenix organization were informed of the 20-year-old law yesterday when they protested a county ban in literature distribution at the County Hospital and Health Department.
County Mgr. Tom M. Sullivan quoted the law as follows:

"Any person who willfully writes, composes or publishes a notice or an advertisement of any medicine or any means of producing or facilitating a miscarriage or abortion, or for prevention of conception, or who offers his services by notice, advertisement or otherwise to assist in the accomplishment of any such purpose is guilty of a misdemeanor."

docBody.p: Mrs. Sanger said, "We looked into that when we first started the clinic here (in 1935) and the only thing we could find that was illegal was to advertise publicly.

"We went to Phoenix then, went through that with the attorney general's office up there and that was what we found. We've always told the Phoenix people not to advertise and I don't believe they have. The first thing they've got to do is get a good lawyer and show they're doing nothing illegal."

p.q: According to Mrs. Frank Hardy, vice president of the board of directors of the local Planned Parenthood Clinic,

"This is so old hat, it isn't even funny. As far as I know, the local clinic isn't distributing literature in the County Hospital here or the Health Department but we try to get all the literature we can out to the public. People who come to the Clinic take literature and read it and pass it on to their friends and each year, during the campaign, we mail it out. Every organization in the country does."
Violation of Arizona law is punishable by a fine not to exceed $300, a jail sentence not to exceed six months, or both.
Charles C. Stidham, Maricopa County attorney, said he would have to issue a complaint against the Phoenix clinic if called upon to do so by any citizen.

docBody.p: Mrs. Sanger indicated she will throw her weight behind the Phoenix clinic in this fight. She said she would go to Phoenix, if necessary, after she ascertains the full extent of the problem.
